title: Boris Johnson has been humiliated and we're laughing at him not with him
text:

Slapdash and amateur, humiliated Boris Johnson’s Saturday Shambles was the incomptence of an unfunny clown.

One Tory Minister, a Brexit true believeer, whispered the Prime Minister has no masterplan. It doesn’t exist.

Instead he flies by the seat of his pants. When an idea fails, he tries another one. Then another one, And another one after that.

Shamelessness is his simple sword of lies and trusty shield of deception.

Remember that Johnson didn’t even believe in the UK leaving the EU until he saw it as the key to No 10.

Yet there’s no dodging the blow to Johnson’s authority when the PM’s legally required to seek an extension of Britain’s membership of the European club.

He won’t do so will Johnson die in a ditch? Not yet is the disappointing answer for those fighting to save Britain in Europe.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

The solemn promise was just another piece of discardable propaganda for Downing Street’s fibber-in-chief.

In fairness to Johnson, it’s possible he could still secure approval for his horror plan to impoverish and destablise this land before Halloween.

Tricky with the clock tickng though possible. Key is persuading betrayed DUP allies to swallow their mortification. The taxpayers’ cheque would require a lot of zeros.

TUC chief Frances O’Grady skilfully highlighting the latest Brexit fraud’s danger to job rights put backbones into Labour waverers toying with supporting Johnson.

No-deal’s worse than Johnson’s bad deal which in turn is inferior to May’s thrice rejected compromise.

Miscalculating we’d be in a General Election now, miscalculating Parliament could be sidelines and miscalculating a Saturday showcase would give him a kiss of approval is a leaden PM lacking the winning touch.

All that could change next week or the week after but for the moment it’s another humiliation for a human rubber ball in danger of losing his bounce.

Southampton headed football’s premier First Division, the Goombay Dance Bank topped the singles chart and the price of a pint was 62p when MPs gathered for the last Saturday debate, on the Falklands, way back in April 1982.

Johnson must wish he’d stayed home and watched England thump Australia in the rugby world cup.

They’re laughing at him, not with, now.
